oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Milk Quality Premiums Received by Wisconsin Dairy Farms Participating in Veterinary-directed Milk Quality Programs
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ruegg, Pamela
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: milk
quality criteria
somatic cell
bacteria
management practices
financial incentives
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: High quality milk is generally defined as adulterant free milk that meets specific quality criteria relating to the level of somatic cells (SCC) and bacteria. In the U.S., production of high quality milk is encouraged by legislating maximum limits of SCC and bacteria, and by financial rewards offered by processors (premiums). This study describes the relationship between measures of milk quality, dairy management practices and financial incentives offered by milk processors on selected Wisconsin dairy farms.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2000; 142-143
